Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Scalable Algorithms for Individual Decision Making in Multiagent Settings

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research under this award is developing efficient and effective methods for strategic decision making by an individual artificial agent cohabiting with other agents in uncertain environments. For example, how should an autonomous unmanned aerial vehicle decide between closer surveillance of a possible fugitive or intercepting the target who may be aware of the monitoring? Toward this goal, the research is identifying the sources of computational complexity and understanding the conflicting interrelationship between computational efficiency and decision-making effectiveness. This problem of individual decision making in uncertain multiagent settings is formalized using a recognized framework that combines the decision-theoretic paradigm of partially observable Markov decision processes (POMDPs) with elements of Bayesian games and interactive epistemology. In this framework, called interactive POMDP (I-POMDP), the research utilizes innovative ways of minimally modeling contextual knowledge in multiagent settings, exploits novel decision-making heuristics and embedded structure in problems.

Integration of research and education is manifest in the development and delivery of a multi-disciplinary course on strategic decision making under uncertainty, which integrates and compares normative theories with real human decision-making behavior.

By combining aspects of decision and game theories, both of which seek to understand normative ways of decision making, with attention to real human decision-making behavior, this research is contributing to long-term research and development of artificial agents that can assist with rational, long-term decision making and planning in areas including emergency response, environmental sustainability, autonomous vehicles and many others.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Imagine yourself as a participant in a game show where you are faced with two closed doors. Opening one door wins you a car worth $10K but opening the other makes you lose all money won so far which happens to be $100K. You have three rounds to win the car. During each round, you may open a door or request the host to give you a clue, who then points out the correct door hiding the car 85% of the times or lies to you 15% of the times. However, the clue costs you $1K each time. Would you request a clue and if so, how many times? Would you ever open a door?

 

The above problem – inspired by the famous Monty Hall problem – is sequential allowing several possible lines of play and involves making decisions under uncertain information. This makes it computationally hard. Nevertheless, we may solve this problem optimally and obtain the solution of opening a door in the third round only after two consistent clues were given previously. Otherwise, we should not open any door. Now imagine that you are competing with another participant in the game show. If a door is opened, the car randomly appears behind a door in the next round. Clearly, the presence of another participant complicates your own decision-making process. Indeed, it becomes computationally far harder as well.

 

This CAREER award facilitated comprehensive investigations into a computational framework for optimal, sequential decision making by an individual agent under uncertain information while sharing its environment with other agents who may have conflicting preferences. As this is a very hard computational problem, the outcomes are of high intellectual merit. Of significance, researchers now have a deeper understanding of the multiple sources of computational intractability that challenge the decision making. A portfolio of methods and algorithms were produced that flexibly trade off optimality of the decisions to enable scalability in multi-agent settings by exploiting problem structures. Insights into when standard solution concepts such as equilibria become inadequate were uncovered, and other solution concepts were developed.

 

The net outcome is a slew of algorithmic advances that now enable decision making (or planning) by an individual agent in far larger problem spaces than previously thought possible. This has helped redefine multi-agent decision making and planning in the last decade, and instilled confidence in other researchers and practitioners about its benefit thereby motivating them to utilize this research in their own applications. For example, some of these algorithms were used by others for academic explorations into countering money laundering, for formally modeling trust between humans and interactive robot learning from teachers, and for simulating human behavioral data pertaining to strategic thought and action in games.

 

Several broader impacts were facilitated by this award as well. Two doctoral students and one masters student supported by this award graduated and joined the STEM workforce of the nation. This award facilitated the development of a popular graduate course on decision making under uncertainty and a well-received tutorial that the principal investigator has co-conducted in conferences since the last seven years.
